Notes: Explain deferred execution vs. immediate execution in detail. Discuss how to build dynamic queries using Expression Trees.
PracticeExercise: Write a function that takes a collection of objects and a string representing a property name and a value. Use Expression Trees to dynamically build a LINQ query that filters the collection based on the property and value.

Notes: Discuss the performance implications of reflection. Explain how to use the Roslyn compiler API for code analysis and generation.
PracticeExercise: Write a simple Roslyn analyzer that identifies and flags the use of DateTime.Now in code, suggesting DateTime.UtcNow as a best practice.

Topic: Async/Await Deep Dive (State Machine, SynchronizationContext, ConfigureAwait)
Notes: Be ready to explain the async state machine and demonstrate with code how a deadlock can occur (e.g., in a UI or classic ASP.NET context) and how ConfigureAwait(false) helps prevent it.
PracticeExercise: Create a simple Console App that calls an async method and blocks on the result (e.g., using .Result or .Wait()). Explain why it deadlocks in some environments. Modify the async method to use ConfigureAwait(false) and explain why that resolves the issue.

Notes: Explain how System.Threading.Tasks.Channels can be used to create efficient producer/consumer workflows. Compare them to other synchronization primitives like BlockingCollection.
PracticeExercise: Implement a background service that processes items from a queue. Use a Channel to pass data from a 'producer' (e.g., a controller endpoint) to a 'consumer' (the background service) in a thread-safe and asynchronous manner.

Notes: Understand common use cases like event-driven architecture and callbacks.
PracticeExercise: Create a 'Worker' class that performs a long-running operation. Define an event in this class called 'ProgressChanged'. Create a UI or Console class that subscribes to this event and reports the progress. Trigger the event from within the worker's operation.

Notes: Explain the differences and when to use each scope in an ASP.NET Core application. Discuss the danger of Captive Dependencies.
PracticeExercise: In an ASP.NET Core API, create a simple service interface (e.g., IOperationLogger) and an implementation that has a unique ID (e.g., a Guid) set in its constructor. Register this service three times: once as Singleton, once as Scoped, and once as Transient. Inject all three into a controller and log their unique IDs on a single request to demonstrate the lifetime differences.

Notes: Understand how the GC works to write memory-efficient code. Explain the Dispose pattern.
PracticeExercise: Create a class that wraps an unmanaged resource (like a file stream). Implement the IDisposable pattern correctly, including a finalizer. Write client code to demonstrate its use with a 'using' statement and explain why both Dispose and the finalizer are needed.

Topic: LINQ Internals (IQueryable vs. IEnumerable, Deferred Execution)
Notes: Explain how this impacts database queries with Entity Framework.
PracticeExercise: Using EF Core and an in-memory database, write a query against a DbSet<Product>. First, use .AsEnumerable() before a .Where() clause and inspect the generated query. Then, write the same logic but use .AsQueryable() (or just chain the .Where() directly) and explain the difference in the executed SQL.

Topic: Memory Management (Stack vs. Heap, Value vs. Reference Types, Boxing/Unboxing)
Notes: Understand value types vs reference types and boxing/unboxing implications.
PracticeExercise: Write code that passes a struct and a class to a method, modifies their properties inside the method, and prints the values before and after the call to demonstrate the difference. Create a scenario that causes extensive boxing and explain the performance hit.

Notes: Distinguish between CPU-bound and I/O-bound operations and when to use threads vs async/await.
PracticeExercise: Write a program that calculates a heavy mathematical sequence (CPU bound) using Parallel.ForEach or Threads. Then write a program that fetches data from multiple URLs (I/O bound) using async/await. Measure and compare the performance and resource usage.

Notes: Understand the startup process, DI container composition, and background services (IHostedService / BackgroundService).
PracticeExercise: Create a .NET Generic Host console application. Register a BackgroundService that runs a periodic task. Explain the application lifecycle events (StartAsync, StopAsync).

Notes: Understand how code can be represented as data and manipulated at runtime. This is key for libraries like EF Core and AutoMapper.
PracticeExercise: Create a simple expression tree manually that represents a lambda expression like 'x => x > 5'. Compile and execute it.

Notes: Know how to work with memory efficiently without allocations, especially for string parsing and buffer manipulation.
PracticeExercise: Write a method that parses a large string (e.g., a comma-separated line) using Substring (creating new strings) and then rewrite it using Span<T> (slice without allocation). Benchmark the two approaches.

Notes: Understand how to stream data asynchronously, which is useful for processing large datasets without loading everything into memory.
PracticeExercise: Create an API endpoint that returns an IAsyncEnumerable<int>. Consume this endpoint from a client application using the 'await foreach' statement.

Notes: Understand how to generate code at compile time to improve performance (avoiding reflection) and reduce boilerplate.
PracticeExercise: Create a simple Source Generator that automatically implements the INotifyPropertyChanged interface for any class decorated with a custom attribute.

Notes: Know when and how to use the 'unsafe' keyword and pointers for interoperability or extreme performance optimization.
PracticeExercise: Write a method using 'unsafe' that copies data from one integer array to another using pointers. Explain the risks involved.

Notes: Deep dive into Claims, Policies, Roles, and custom Authorization Handlers.
PracticeExercise: Implement a custom Authorization Handler that checks a specific claim (e.g., 'OfficeLocation') and logic (e.g., 'must be in NY'). Register it as a Policy and apply it to a Controller.

Notes: Discuss how to prevent common vulnerabilities (e.g., SQL Injection, XSS, CSRF) within the ASP.NET Core framework.
PracticeExercise: Create an API endpoint that takes a raw string and uses it to build a SQL query with string concatenation. Explain why this is vulnerable to SQL Injection. Refactor the code to use parameterized queries (e.g., with Dapper or EF Core's FromSqlRaw) to prevent the vulnerability.

Notes: Explain common schemes like JWT, OAuth 2.0, OpenID Connect, and Cookie-based authentication.
PracticeExercise: Create two API endpoints. Secure one with [Authorize]. Secure the second with a custom policy-based authorization requirement (e.g., [Authorize(Policy = IsAdmin")]). Implement the policy and handler to check for a specific claim in the user's identity."

Topic: Configuration Management (appsettings, User Secrets, Environment Variables, Azure Key Vault)
Notes: Understand the configuration hierarchy and how to manage secrets safely.
PracticeExercise: Create an app that reads settings from appsettings.json, environment variables, and User Secrets. Show how environment variables override appsettings values.

Notes: Describe the filter pipeline and provide use cases for each type of filter.
PracticeExercise: Create a custom Action Filter attribute that logs the time it takes for an action method to execute. Apply this filter to a controller action and verify that it logs the timing information correctly.

Notes: Explain how the request pipeline is built and the importance of middleware ordering.
PracticeExercise: Create a custom middleware component that logs the request path and a custom response header. Register it in the pipeline. Then, register a second piece of middleware that short-circuits the pipeline (doesn't call next). Demonstrate how changing the order of these two middleware components affects the application's behavior.

Notes: Move validation logic out of controllers and DTOs into dedicated validators.
PracticeExercise: Integrate FluentValidation into an ASP.NET Core project. Create a complex validator for a 'UserRegistration' DTO that checks if the email is unique (simulated DB check) and if the password meets complexity requirements.

Notes: Maintain clear docs for 24/7 operations.
PracticeExercise: Add Swashbuckle (Swagger) to an API. Configure it to generate XML comments documentation. Decorate a controller action with [ProducesResponseType] attributes to document possible HTTP status codes.

Topic: API Versioning Strategies (URL, Header, Query String)
Notes: Discuss the pros and cons of each approach.
PracticeExercise: Using the Asp.Versioning.Mvc library, create a single controller with two action methods that respond to the same route. One method should be for API version 1.0, and the other for 2.0. Configure the application to support URL-segment-based versioning (e.g., /api/v1/products).

Notes: Understand Cross-Origin Resource Sharing and how to configure it securely.
PracticeExercise: Create an API and a separate simple HTML/JS client running on a different port. Configure CORS in the API to allow requests only from the client's origin.

Notes: Understand when to use gRPC (internal microservices) vs REST (public APIs).
PracticeExercise: Create a simple gRPC service definition (.proto file). Implement the service in ASP.NET Core. Create a client to consume it and compare the code/performance to a standard REST controller.

Notes: Implement health checks for dependencies (DB, external APIs). Understand Retry, Circuit Breaker patterns.
PracticeExercise: Add Health Checks to an API to report the status of the database connection. Use Polly to wrap an external HTTP call with a Retry policy (retry 3 times with exponential backoff).

Notes: Understand the differences and when to use each hosting model.
PracticeExercise: Dockerize a simple ASP.NET Core API. Run it in a container. Compare this to running it directly on IIS Express (if possible) or via Kestrel.

Notes: Avoid socket exhaustion issues and manage HttpClient lifetimes properly.
PracticeExercise: Register a named HttpClient in the DI container. Inject IHttpClientFactory into a service and use it to create a client to call an external API.

Notes: Contrast the Minimal API approach with the traditional Controller-based approach.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a simple Controller-based API endpoint (e.g., GetWeather) into a Minimal API endpoint in Program.cs. Discuss the pros and cons (boilerplate vs structure).

Notes: Optimize API performance by reducing bandwidth and server load.
PracticeExercise: Implement Response Caching in a controller. Use the [ResponseCache] attribute. Also, enable Response Compression middleware for the application.

Notes: Understanding the development process.
PracticeExercise: Explain the difference between Scrum and Kanban. Describe the purpose of key ceremonies (Daily Standup

Notes: Soft skills and cultural fit.
PracticeExercise: Prepare answers for common questions: 'Tell me about a time you failed', 'How do you handle conflict', 'Describe a challenging project'. Use the Situation, Task, Action, Result format.

Notes: Quality assurance and team collaboration.
PracticeExercise: Explain what you look for in a code review (readability
column10: performance). How do you give constructive feedback?

Topic: System Design (Scalability, Load Balancing, Caching, CAP Theorem)
Notes: Designing scalable systems.
PracticeExercise: Design a URL Shortener service (like bit.ly). Discuss database choice, ID generation strategy, caching layers, and handling high read traffic.

Notes: Explaining complex concepts to non-technical stakeholders.
PracticeExercise: Explain 'Recursion' or 'DNS' to a 5-year-old (or a non-technical project manager).

Notes: Logging, Tracing, Alerts.
PracticeExercise: Integrate Application Insights into a .NET Core app. Generate some traffic and inspect the 'Failures' and 'Performance' blades in the Azure Portal.

Notes: Deploying Web Apps, Slots, Scaling.
PracticeExercise: Deploy a web app to Azure App Service. Configure a 'Staging' deployment slot. Swap Staging to Production.

Notes: Triggers (HTTP, Timer, Queue), Bindings.
PracticeExercise: Create an Azure Function triggered by an HTTP request that puts a message onto an Azure Storage Queue.

Notes: Managed databases and cloud storage options.
PracticeExercise: Write a small app that uploads a file to Azure Blob Storage and saves metadata to Azure SQL (or Table Storage).

Notes: Build, Test, and Release automation.
PracticeExercise: Create a GitHub Action or Azure DevOps Pipeline that builds a .NET project, runs tests, and (if successful) deploys it to an Azure App Service.

Notes: Secret management.
PracticeExercise: Store a database connection string in Key Vault. Configure the App Service to read this secret using Managed Identity (no passwords in code!).

Notes: Messaging patterns (Queues, Topics).
PracticeExercise: Create a Service Bus Topic. Write a publisher app that sends messages. Write two subscriber apps that listen to the same topic but different subscriptions (Pub/Sub pattern).

Notes: Basics of Docker files, composing, and orchestration.
PracticeExercise: Write a Dockerfile for a .NET app. Build the image. Push it to Azure Container Registry (ACR). Deploy it to a local Kubernetes cluster (or AKS).

Notes: Caching strategies in a distributed environment.
PracticeExercise: Implement Redis caching in a .NET app using the IDistributedCache interface. Cache a value and retrieve it.

Notes: Provisioning resources via code.
PracticeExercise: Write a Bicep or Terraform script to provision an Azure Resource Group and an App Service Plan.

Notes: API Gateway
PracticeExercise: Service Discovery (conceptually).
link: Design a simple microservices system diagram using Azure API Management (APIM) as a gateway and Azure Container Apps for hosting services.

Notes: Modern auth flows.
PracticeExercise: Register an application in Azure AD. Configure a .NET Core API to protect endpoints using Azure AD Bearer tokens.

Notes: Handle the 'Lost Update' problem.
PracticeExercise: Implement Optimistic Concurrency Control using a RowVersion (Timestamp) column in EF Core. Write a test case where two users try to update the same record simultaneously and handle the DbUpdateConcurrencyException.

Topic: EF Core (Change Tracking, Loading Strategies: Eager, Explicit, Lazy)
Notes: Understand the difference between Tracking and NoTracking queries, and Eager vs Lazy loading.
PracticeExercise: Create a scenario where accessing a navigation property triggers an N+1 query problem (Lazy Loading). Fix it using Eager Loading (.Include). Then demonstrate an Explicit Load.

Topic: EF Core Performance Tuning (AsNoTracking, Compiled Queries, Query Splitting)
Notes: Know techniques to optimize EF Core read/write performance.
PracticeExercise: Write a query that retrieves a large dataset. Optimize it using AsNoTracking(). Then, use Compiled Queries (or just explain the concept) to improve reuse performance. Use Query Splitting for a complex join.

Notes: Ability to read an execution plan and identify missing indexes or scans vs seeks.
PracticeExercise: Given a slow SQL query generated by an app, analyze its execution plan in SSMS (or Azure Data Studio). identifying a Table Scan. Create an appropriate Non-Clustered Index to convert it to an Index Seek.

Notes: Understand Dirty Reads
PracticeExercise: Non-Repeatable Reads
column9: Write two console apps that act as concurrent transactions. Demonstrate a Dirty Read by having one transaction read uncommitted data from the other. Fix it by changing the Isolation Level to Read Committed.

Notes: Clustered vs Non-Clustered, Filtered Indexes, Included Columns.
PracticeExercise: Create a query that requires sorting and filtering. Create a Composite Index that satisfies both requirements (Covering Index) so the query doesn't need to touch the main table (Key Lookup).

Notes: Know when to use a micro-ORM (Dapper) vs a full ORM (EF Core).
PracticeExercise: Implement a high-performance read operation using Dapper for a complex report query. Compare the implementation code and execution speed with the equivalent EF Core LINQ query.

Notes: Know how to configure entities without polluting the model classes.
PracticeExercise: Take an Entity class with Data Annotations (e.g., [Key], [Required]). Remove them and implement the same configuration using the Fluent API in the DbContext OnModelCreating method.

Notes: Implement Soft Delete or Multi-tenancy automatically.
PracticeExercise: Implement a Soft Delete pattern (IsDeleted column). Configure a Global Query Filter in EF Core so that all queries automatically exclude deleted records. Demonstrate how to bypass this filter using IgnoreQueryFilters().

Notes: Hook into EF Core operations for logging or auditing.
PracticeExercise: Create an EF Core Interceptor that logs every SQL command to the console before it is executed. Or, implement an interceptor that automatically updates 'CreatedBy' and 'CreatedDate' fields on SaveChanges.

Notes: Manage database schema changes in production safely.
PracticeExercise: Create a migration that adds a new column. Then, assume the requirement changed. Remove the migration (if not applied) or create a new migration to rename the column. Explain how to generate an SQL script from migrations for production deployment.

Notes: Understand how to cache query results to reduce DB load (using libraries like EFCore.SecondLevelCacheInterceptor).
PracticeExercise: Configure Second-Level Caching in an EF Core project (using a library or conceptually explaining it). Cache the results of a commonly used reference data query (e.g., 'GetCountries').

Topic: EF Core Shadow Properties & Backing Fields
Notes: Work with properties that are not in the .NET class definition but exist in the DB.
PracticeExercise: Configure a Shadow Property 'LastUpdated' for an entity. specific that it should be managed by the DbContext, not the entity class.

Topic: Executing Raw SQL and Stored Procedures
Notes: How to drop down to raw SQL when EF is too slow or limited.
PracticeExercise: Write a complex Stored Procedure in the DB. Call it from EF Core using .FromSqlRaw() or .ExecuteSqlRaw(). Map the result back to a Domain Entity or a custom DTO.

Notes: Understand when to choose NoSQL (CosmosDB, Mongo) over SQL.
PracticeExercise: Design a data model for a 'User Session' store or a 'Product Catalog' with dynamic attributes. Explain why a Document DB (like MongoDB or CosmosDB) might be better than a Relational DB for this specific use case.

Notes: Scaffolding a DbContext from a legacy DB.
PracticeExercise: Use the 'dotnet ef dbcontext scaffold' command to generate entity classes and a DbContext from an existing SQL Server database.

Notes: Recognize and apply common patterns to solve recurring problems.
PracticeExercise: Implement the Strategy Pattern for a Payment Processing system (e.g., CreditCardStrategy, PaypalStrategy). Allow the client to switch strategies at runtime.

Notes: The foundation of clean object-oriented design.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a 'God Class' that violates SRP (Single Responsibility) and OCP (Open/Closed). Break it down into smaller classes/interfaces. Show how you can now extend functionality without modifying existing code.

Notes: Separation of concerns
PracticeExercise: Dependency Rule.
link: Create a solution structure following Clean Architecture (Core, Infrastructure, Web/API). Implement a simple use case ensuring the Core layer has no dependencies on Infrastructure.

Notes: Separating read and write models.
PracticeExercise: Implement a simplified CQRS pattern using MediatR. Create a Command to update data and a Query to read data, handled by separate handlers.

Notes: Entities
PracticeExercise: Value Objects
column10: Model a 'Order' Aggregate Root that contains a list of 'OrderItem' entities. Ensure that OrderItems can only be added via a method on the Order class (Encapsulation), enforcing invariants (e.g., max quantity).

Notes: Saga)
PracticeExercise: Medium
column9: Explain the Saga pattern for a distributed transaction (e.g., Order -> Payment -> Inventory). Implement a simulated compensation action if one step fails.

Notes: Storing state as a sequence of events.
PracticeExercise: Create a simple BankAccount class that reconstructs its balance by replaying a list of 'Deposited' and 'Withdrawn' events.

Notes: A pragmatic alternative to microservices.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a monolithic app into distinct Modules (e.g., Catalog, Cart) that enforce boundaries (internal classes) and communicate only via public APIs or events.

Notes: Event-driven designs.
PracticeExercise: Design a system where a file upload to Blob Storage triggers a Function to process it, which then updates a database. Draw the flow.

Notes: Encapsulating query logic.
PracticeExercise: Create a Specification class 'ActiveProductsSpec' that encapsulates the logic 'IsActive == true && Stock > 0'. Use it to filter a repository query.

Notes: Test the entire pipeline without hitting a real database (or using a test DB).
PracticeExercise: Create an integration test for an API endpoint using WebApplicationFactory. Mock the database layer (or use an In-Memory/Docker DB) and assert that the endpoint returns the correct HTTP status code and JSON response.

Notes: Isolate the unit under test.
PracticeExercise: Write a unit test for a Service class that depends on a Repository. Use Moq to mock the Repository's method to return a specific value. Assert that the Service logic handles this value correctly.

Notes: Write clean, maintainable tests.
PracticeExercise: Take a complex method with multiple execution paths. Write unit tests covering the 'Happy Path' and at least two edge cases (e.g., null input, empty list). Follow the AAA pattern.

Notes: Useful for testing complex object structures or UI rendering.
PracticeExercise: Write a test that serializes a complex object graph and compares it to a stored 'baseline' snapshot. Fail the test if they differ.

Notes: Understand the Red-Green-Refactor cycle.
PracticeExercise: Choose a simple algorithm (e.g., String Calculator). Write a failing test first. Write the minimal code to pass it. Refactor. Repeat.

Notes: JD Requirement: Deploy and manage applications on AWS. Understand Compute (EC2), Storage (S3), and Database (RDS).
PracticeExercise: Create a free-tier AWS account. Launch an EC2 instance with Java installed. Connect to it via SSH. Create an S3 bucket and write a Java program using the AWS SDK to upload a file to it.

Notes: JD Requirement: Experience with Jenkins, GitLab CI/CD.
PracticeExercise: Set up a local Jenkins instance (using Docker). Create a Pipeline job that pulls a simple Java project from Git, builds it with Maven/Gradle, and runs unit tests.

Notes: Clustered vs Non-Clustered, Filtered Indexes, Included Columns.
PracticeExercise: Create a query that requires sorting and filtering. Create a Composite Index that satisfies both requirements (Covering Index) so the query doesn't need to touch the main table (Key Lookup).

Notes: JD Requirement: Expert in Oracle/PostgreSQL. Ability to read execution plans (Explain Analyze), identify Sequential Scans vs Index Scans, and optimize complex joins.
PracticeExercise: Install PostgreSQL. Write a query that performs a sequential scan. Analyze with 'EXPLAIN ANALYZE'. Create a composite index to convert it to an Index Scan/Seek. Compare performance.

Notes: Handle the 'Lost Update' problem.
PracticeExercise: Implement Optimistic Concurrency Control using a RowVersion (Timestamp) column in EF Core. Write a test case where two users try to update the same record simultaneously and handle the DbUpdateConcurrencyException.

Notes: Implement Soft Delete or Multi-tenancy automatically.
PracticeExercise: Implement a Soft Delete pattern (IsDeleted column). Configure a Global Query Filter in EF Core so that all queries automatically exclude deleted records. Demonstrate how to bypass this filter using IgnoreQueryFilters().

Notes: Know techniques to optimize EF Core read/write performance.
PracticeExercise: Write a query that retrieves a large dataset. Optimize it using AsNoTracking(). Then, use Compiled Queries (or just explain the concept) to improve reuse performance. Use Query Splitting for a complex join.

Notes: Know how to configure entities without polluting the model classes.
PracticeExercise: Take an Entity class with Data Annotations (e.g., [Key], [Required]). Remove them and implement the same configuration using the Fluent API in the Repository OnModelCreating method.

Notes: Understand the difference between Tracking and NoTracking queries, and Eager vs Lazy loading.
PracticeExercise: Create a scenario where accessing a navigation property triggers an N+1 query problem (Lazy Loading). Fix it using Eager Loading (JOIN FETCH).

Notes: Know when to use a micro-ORM (MyBatis/jOOQ) vs a full ORM (Hibernate).
PracticeExercise: Implement a high-performance read operation using MyBatis or jOOQ for a complex report query. Compare execution speed with the equivalent Hibernate query.

Notes: How to drop down to raw SQL when EF is too slow or limited.
PracticeExercise: Write a complex Stored Procedure in the DB. Call it from EF Core using .FromSqlRaw() or .ExecuteSqlRaw(). Map the result back to a Domain Entity or a custom DTO.

Notes: Understand when to choose NoSQL (CosmosDB, Mongo) over SQL.
PracticeExercise: Design a data model for a 'User Session' store or a 'Product Catalog' with dynamic attributes. Explain why a Document DB (like MongoDB or CosmosDB) might be better than a Relational DB for this specific use case.

Notes: Understand Dirty Reads
PracticeExercise: Non-Repeatable Reads
column9: Write two console apps that act as concurrent transactions. Demonstrate a Dirty Read by having one transaction read uncommitted data from the other. Fix it by changing the Isolation Level to Read Committed.

Notes: Be ready to explain the async state machine and demonstrate with code how a deadlock can occur (e.g., in a UI or classic Spring Boot context) and how appropriate executor configuration helps prevent it.
PracticeExercise: Create a simple Console App that calls an async method and blocks on the result (e.g., .get() or .join()). Explain why it deadlocks in some environments. Modify the async method to use appropriate executor configuration.

Notes: Explain the differences and when to use each scope in an Spring Boot Core application.
PracticeExercise: In an Spring Boot Core API, create a simple service interface (e.g., IOperationLogger) and an implementation that has a unique ID. Register this service three times: Singleton, Scoped, and Transient. Inject all three into a controller and log their unique IDs.

Topic: Garbage Collection (G1, ZGC, Memory Leaks, try-with-resources)
Notes: Understand how the GC works to write memory-efficient code. Explain the close pattern.
PracticeExercise: Create a class that wraps an unmanaged resource (like a file stream). Implement the AutoCloseable pattern correctly, including a finalizer. Write client code to demonstrate its use with a 'try-with-resources' statement.

Notes: JD Requirement: Preferred skill. Learn basic syntax, closures, and how to write Jenkinsfiles.
PracticeExercise: Write a simple Groovy script that parses a JSON file and prints specific fields. Then, write a mock 'Jenkinsfile' using declarative syntax that defines a Build, Test, and Deploy stage.

Topic: Memory Management (Stack vs. Heap, References, Pass-by-Value)
Notes: Understand value types vs reference types and boxing/unboxing implications.
PracticeExercise: Write code that passes a primitive and a class to a method, modifies their properties inside the method, and prints the values before and after the call to demonstrate the difference.

Notes: Understand the startup process, DI container composition, and background services (SmartLifecycle / CommandLineRunner).
PracticeExercise: Create a Spring Boot console application. Register a SmartLifecycle / CommandLineRunner that runs a periodic task. Explain the application lifecycle events (Start, Stop).

Topic: Stream API Internals (Streams vs Collections, Lazy Evaluation)
Notes: Explain how this impacts database queries with Hibernate.
PracticeExercise: Using Hibernate and an in-memory database, write a query against a Repository<Product>. First, use .stream() before a .filter() clause and inspect the generated query. Then, write the same logic but use JPQL/Criteria API directly and explain the difference in the executed SQL.

Notes: JD Requirement: Automate unit and integration testing. Understand mocking vs integration testing with real dependencies (Docker).
PracticeExercise: Write a unit test for a Service using Mockito to mock the Repository. Then, write an Integration Test using Testcontainers to spin up a real PostgreSQL DB and verify the Repository logic.

Notes: JD Requirement: 'Perform root cause analysis'. Understand the lifecycle of an incident and how to document an RCA.
PracticeExercise: Draft a mock RCA document for a 'High CPU Usage' incident. Include sections for: Timeline, Impact, Root Cause (5 Whys), and Preventative Actions.

Notes: Recognize and apply common patterns to solve recurring problems.
PracticeExercise: Implement the Strategy Pattern for a Payment Processing system (e.g., CreditCardStrategy, PaypalStrategy). Allow the client to switch strategies at runtime.

Notes: The foundation of clean object-oriented design.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a 'God Class' that violates SRP (Single Responsibility) and OCP (Open/Closed). Break it down into smaller classes/interfaces.

Notes: Maintain clear docs for 24/7 operations. Understand versioning (URL, Header) to avoid breaking changes.
PracticeExercise: Add SpringDoc (Swagger) to an API. Configure it to generate docs. Implement API Versioning (v1/v2) using a URI path strategy.

Notes: Focus on SQL Injection, XSS, and CSRF prevention in Spring Boot.
PracticeExercise: Demonstrate a SQL injection vulnerability using raw SQL interpolation. Then fix it using parameterized queries (or Hibernate).

Notes: Clear understanding of Identity (Who are you?) vs Permissions (What can you do?).
PracticeExercise: Set up JWT Authentication in an API. Create a policy-based authorization requirement (e.g., 'Must be at least 18 years old') and apply it to an endpoint.

Notes: JD Requirement: Docker and Kubernetes experience.
PracticeExercise: Dockerize a simple Spring Boot API. Create a Kubernetes deployment manifest (YAML) to run 2 replicas of the app. Explain the difference between a Pod and a Service.

Notes: Contrast the Reactive approach with the traditional Controller-based approach.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a simple Controller-based API endpoint (e.g., GetWeather) into a Functional Endpoint in a Configuration class. Discuss the pros and cons.

Notes: Implement health checks for dependencies (DB, external APIs). Understand Retry, Circuit Breaker patterns.
PracticeExercise: Add Spring Boot Actuator to an API. Expose the /health endpoint. Use Resilience4j to wrap an external HTTP call with a Retry policy.

Notes: Understand the order of execution (Middleware, Filters, Endpoint) and the responsibility of each.
PracticeExercise: Create a custom filter that logs the request and response time. Register it in the pipeline. Then create an Interceptor that logs the specific action being executed. Observe the order of logs.

Notes: Know the different filter types and their execution order.
PracticeExercise: Implement an Authorization Interceptor that checks for a specific custom header. If missing, short-circuit the request. Implement an Exception Handler (@ControllerAdvice) to handle global errors.

Notes: Discuss the differences between Flexbox and Grid and when to use each. Explain concepts like flex-grow, justify-content, and grid-template-columns.
PracticeExercise: Recreate a complex, responsive web page layout (like a news site or e-commerce product page) using a combination of CSS Grid for the overall structure and Flexbox for component alignment.

Notes: Explain how JavaScript interacts with the DOM. Discuss event bubbling  capturing  and delegation.
PracticeExercise: Build a simple to-do list application using vanilla JavaScript. Users should be able to add, delete, and mark items as complete. Use event delegation for the delete and complete actions.

Notes: Explain the importance of semantic HTML for SEO and accessibility (WCAG). Differentiate between div/span and semantic tags like article, nav, etc.
PracticeExercise: Audit a simple webpage for accessibility issues. Refactor non-semantic elements (divs used for buttons or headers) into their correct semantic counterparts (button, h1, etc.) and add necessary ARIA attributes.

Notes: Explain key ES6+ features: Promises, async/await, let/const, arrow functions, and modules. Discuss the browser's event loop.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a piece of callback-based asynchronous code (callback hell) to use Promises, and then again using async/await. Explain the improvements in readability and error handling.

Notes: Discuss key web performance metrics (e.g., LCP, FID, CLS). Explain techniques for optimizing performance, such as lazy loading images, code splitting, and browser caching.
PracticeExercise: Use Lighthouse in Chrome DevTools to audit a web page. Identify performance bottlenecks and implement at least two suggested optimizations (e.g., compressing images, minifying CSS/JS).

Topic: Web Workers for Offloading Main Thread
Notes: Explain what Web Workers are and how they can be used to run scripts in the background to prevent a web page from becoming unresponsive during long-running tasks.
PracticeExercise: Create a simple web page with a button that performs an expensive calculation (e.g., calculating a large number of Fibonacci numbers). First, run it on the main thread and show that the UI freezes. Then, refactor it to use a Web Worker for the calculation, demonstrating that the UI remains responsive.

Topic: Advanced State Management with Zustand or Jotai
Notes: Discuss the limitations of Context for high-frequency updates. Explain the core concepts of a modern state management library like Zustand (store-based) or Jotai (atom-based).
PracticeExercise: Create a simple counter application. First, implement it using React's useState. Then, refactor it to use Zustand for state management. Explain the benefits of this approach in a larger application.

Notes: Explain the difference between functional and class components. Discuss the component lifecycle and the purpose of key lifecycle methods or their Hook equivalents (useEffect).
PracticeExercise: Create a reusable React component (e.g., a data table or a modal) and pass props to it. Manage its state and handle events within the component.

Notes: Explain the concept of micro-frontends and the problems they solve. Discuss different implementation strategies (e.g., module federation).
PracticeExercise: Conceptually design a micro-frontend architecture for an e-commerce site. Decide which parts of the site would be separate micro-frontends (e.g., product search, shopping cart, recommendations) and how they would be composed into a single application.

Notes: Explain the purpose and usage of useState, useEffect, useContext, and useReducer. Discuss the rules of Hooks.
PracticeExercise: Refactor a class component that uses lifecycle methods (componentDidMount, componentDidUpdate) and state into a functional component using useState and useEffect hooks.

Notes: Discuss common performance bottlenecks in React and how to solve them. Explain concepts like memoization (React.memo), useCallback, useMemo, and code splitting.
PracticeExercise: Given a slow-rendering React component with an expensive calculation, use useMemo to optimize it. Profile the component using React DevTools before and after to demonstrate the performance improvement.

Notes: Explain how to implement client-side routing. Discuss strategies for fetching data from an API  including handling loading and error states.
PracticeExercise: Create a multi-page application using React Router. One page should fetch data from a public API (e.g., GitHub or a weather API) and display it to the user, correctly handling the loading and error UI states.

Notes: Explain the difference between unit and end-to-end testing in a React context. Discuss the roles of libraries like Jest and React Testing Library.
PracticeExercise: Write unit tests for a React component using Jest and React Testing Library. The tests should cover rendering, user interaction (e.g., clicking a button), and state changes.

Topic: SSR, SSG, and ISR with Next.js/Remix
Notes: Explain the differences between Server-Side Rendering, Static Site Generation, and Incremental Static Regeneration. Discuss the trade-offs and which to use for different types of web pages (e.g., a blog vs. a user dashboard).
PracticeExercise: Create a simple Next.js application with three pages: one that uses SSG (e.g., an 'About' page), one that uses SSR (e.g., a user-specific 'Profile' page), and one that uses ISR (e.g., a 'Products' page that revalidates every 60 seconds).

Notes: Discuss the benefits of using a state machine for managing complex component state, such as preventing impossible states. Give a brief overview of a library like XState.
PracticeExercise: Model a simple data fetching component's state (e.g., 'idle', 'loading', 'success', 'error') as a state machine using XState. Integrate this machine into a React component to manage the UI based on the current state.

Notes: Discuss different state management strategies in large-scale React applications. Compare and contrast Redux and the Context API.
PracticeExercise: Build a small application with a global theme (light/dark mode). Implement the theme toggle twice: once using the Context API and once using Redux. Discuss the pros and cons of each approach for this use case.

Notes: Understand Dijkstra's algorithm for shortest path in a weighted graph and topological sort for ordering tasks with dependencies. Be aware of algorithms like A* and Prim's/Kruskal's for Minimum Spanning Trees.
PracticeExercise: Implement Dijkstra's algorithm to find the shortest path between two nodes in a weighted graph. Given a list of courses and their prerequisites, find a valid order to take the courses (Topological Sort).

Notes: Be familiar with advanced algorithms like Rabin-Karp for substring search and algorithms for finding the longest palindromic substring.
PracticeExercise: Implement the Rabin-Karp algorithm to find all occurrences of a pattern in a text. Find the longest palindromic substring in a given string.

Topic: Arrays & Strings - Core Operations and Patterns
Notes: Focus on time/space complexity. Master patterns like Two Pointers, Sliding Window, and Prefix Sums for solving a wide range of problems efficiently.
PracticeExercise: Implement the Two Sum problem. Given a sorted array, square each element and return the sorted result. Find the maximum sum of any contiguous subarray of size 'k' (Sliding Window).

Notes: This is the absolute foundation. Be able to analyze the time and space complexity of any algorithm you write or discuss. Understand O(1), O(log n), O(n), O(n log n), O(n^2), O(2^n).
PracticeExercise: For every DSA practice problem you solve, verbally and in code comments, analyze and state the time and space complexity of your solution. Explain the reasoning. Compare the complexity of brute-force vs. optimized solutions.

Notes: Know the properties of a BST. Understand the time complexity for search, insertion, and deletion. Be able to validate if a given tree is a BST.
PracticeExercise: Implement search, insert, and delete operations for a BST. Write a function to validate if a binary tree is a valid BST. Find the lowest common ancestor (LCA) of two nodes in a BST.

Notes: Understand basic bitwise operators (AND, OR, XOR, NOT, shifts). Know their use cases for efficient problem-solving, such as finding a missing number, checking for powers of two, or managing sets of flags.
PracticeExercise: Given an array where every element appears twice except for one, find the single element using XOR. Check if a number is a power of two using bitwise operators. Count the number of set bits (1s) in an integer.

Notes: Understand how this paradigm breaks problems into smaller subproblems, solves them recursively, and combines the results. Recognize Merge Sort and Quick Sort as classic examples.
PracticeExercise: Find the maximum and minimum elements in an array using the divide and conquer approach. Implement Karatsuba's algorithm for fast multiplication of large numbers.

Notes: This is a critical topic for senior interviews. Be able to identify a DP problem by recognizing optimal substructure and overlapping subproblems. Differentiate between memoization (top-down) and tabulation (bottom-up) approaches.
PracticeExercise: Solve the Climbing Stairs problem. Find the maximum sum of a non-adjacent subarray. Solve the Coin Change problem. Find the Longest Common Subsequence of two strings.

Notes: Understand adjacency list vs. adjacency matrix representations and their trade-offs. Be proficient in Breadth-First Search (BFS) for shortest path in unweighted graphs and Depth-First Search (DFS) for traversal and cycle detection.
PracticeExercise: Implement BFS and DFS for a given graph. Clone a graph. Find the number of connected components in an undirected graph. Detect a cycle in a directed graph.

Notes: Understand the greedy approach of making a locally optimal choice at each step. Be able to prove or disprove whether a greedy strategy works for a given problem.
PracticeExercise: Solve the Coin Change problem using a greedy approach and explain why it doesn't work for all coin denominations (contrasting it with the DP solution). Implement Huffman coding. Solve the Activity Selection problem.

Notes: This is one of the most important data structures. Understand how hashing works, and discuss collision resolution strategies (chaining vs. open addressing) and their trade-offs.
PracticeExercise: Implement a HashMap from scratch with basic get, put, and delete operations, using chaining for collision resolution. Use a Dictionary to solve problems like finding the first non-repeating character in a string or checking if two arrays have a common item.

Notes: Understand the properties of a heap and how they are typically implemented using an array. Know their use cases for priority queues and finding the K-th smallest/largest element.
PracticeExercise: Implement a Min-Heap from scratch with insert and extractMin operations. Use a Min-Heap to find the 'K' largest elements in an array. Find the median from a data stream.

Notes: Understand the trade-offs vs. arrays. Be proficient in manipulating pointers. Master patterns like the Fast & Slow Pointer technique for cycle detection and finding the middle element.
PracticeExercise: Reverse a singly linked list. Detect if a linked list has a cycle. Merge two sorted linked lists. Find the middle element of a linked list.

Notes: Master recursion as a problem-solving technique. Understand the backtracking template for solving problems involving permutations, combinations, and subsets. Be mindful of the call stack and potential for stack overflow.
PracticeExercise: Generate all possible subsets of a given set. Find all permutations of a string. Solve the N-Queens problem. Implement a Sudoku solver.

Notes: Know the implementation and complexity of Bubble Sort, Insertion Sort, Merge Sort, Quick Sort, and Radix Sort. Deeply understand the trade-offs, especially for Quick Sort (pivot choice, in-place operation) and Merge Sort (space complexity). Master Binary Search.
PracticeExercise: Implement Merge Sort and Quick Sort from scratch. Implement binary search on a sorted array. Given a rotated sorted array, find a target element.

Notes: Understand their LIFO/FIFO principles. Know common use cases: Stacks for parsing, recursion simulation, and reversing. Queues for BFS and task scheduling.
PracticeExercise: Implement a Queue using two Stacks. Solve the Valid Parentheses problem. Implement a basic calculator to evaluate a string expression. Find the first non-repeating character in a stream of characters.

Notes: Be able to implement and explain the differences between In-order, Pre-order, and Post-order (DFS variations) and Level-order (BFS) traversals, both recursively and iteratively.
PracticeExercise: Implement all four traversal methods for a given binary tree. Find the maximum depth of a binary tree. Check if a binary tree is symmetric (a mirror of itself).

Notes: Understand the structure of a Trie and its efficiency for string prefix problems. Know use cases like autocomplete and spell checkers.
PracticeExercise: Implement a Trie from scratch with insert, search, and startsWith methods. Use the Trie to build a simple autocomplete system that suggests words based on a given prefix.
